cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Big Desert.

  • There is a bushfire 45km north of Telopea Downs that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is located in a highly remote area within the Big Desert Wilderness Area.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Aircraft are responding to this fire. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment & Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 12/11/2023 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: 45km north of Telopea Downs
Issue Date: Saturday 11 November 2023, 05:21 pm
Next Update: Sunday 12 November 2023, 12:30 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/30962/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Big Desert.

- There is a bushfire 45km north of Telopea Downs that is not yet under control.
- The bushfire is located in a highly remote area within the Big Desert Wilderness Area.


There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Katandra West, Marungi, Tallygaroopna.
  • There is a haystack fire on Labuan Road.
  • The fire is under control
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.   

Health information: 
  • If you need medical advice for exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. 
  • Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).     
Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

        There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Penshurst.

  • There is a strong non-toxic chemical smell travelling from the area of the Reserve towards Chesswass Street. 
  • Emergency Services are currently responding to this incident.
  • The following road is closed: Chesswas Street 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority. 

Unless the situation changes this will be the last message for this incident.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vichazmat).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Incident Location: Chesswas St, Penshurst

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/30961/moreinfo

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for the North East weather district.
  • People may experience asthma symptoms or difficulty breathing due to thunderstorm activity.
  • Thunderstorm asthma can be triggered by a combination of high amounts of grass pollen in the air and a certain type of thunderstorm. For people who have asthma or hay fever this, can trigger severe asthma symptoms.
  • If you're experiencing wheezing, breathlessness, a feeling of tightness in the chest or a persistent cough, you may be having an asthma attack. 
  • An asthma attack is serious and can be life threatening.
If you develop symptoms follow your asthma management plan, or if you don’t have a plan follow the four steps of asthma first aid. 
Be aware of an increased chance of experiencing breathing difficulties or an asthma attack. Prepare now - carry your asthma reliever puffer with you at all times today.

Call Triple Zero (000) immediately if someone is not breathing, if their asthma suddenly becomes worse or is not improving, or if the person is having an asthma attack and a reliever is not available.

What you should do:

  • If you have asthma, or a history of asthma, carry a reliever puffer (usually blue) on you at all times.
  • Avoid the wind gusts before the storm. Go inside and close your windows and doors.
  • Turn off air conditioners that bring in air from the outside (ie evaporative air conditioners).
If you are experiencing asthma symptoms for the first time:
  • Don’t ignore them; use the four steps of asthma first aid.
  • If required, use asthma first aid. Remember that asthma relievers are available from pharmacies without a prescription. 
  • Make sure you follow up with your doctor.
  • If your asthma suddenly becomes worse or is not improving, or if you are having an asthma attack and a reliever is not available, call Triple Zero (000) immediately.
For health advice:
  • Call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24 or see your doctor if you require medical advice.
  • If you need urgent attention, visit your local Priority Primary Care Centre.
  • In a non-life threatening emergency, contact the Victorian Virtual Emergency Department. 
  • In a life threatening emergency, call Triple Zero (000) immediately. 

Asthma First Aid
If a person is having an asthma attack, use the four steps of asthma first aid: 

Step 1: Sit the person upright. 

Step 2: Give four separate puffs of blue or grey reliever puffer, make sure you shake the puffer, put one puff into the spacer and get the person to take four breaths from the spacer. Repeat this until the person has taken four puffs. 

Step 3: Wait four minutes. If there is no improvement, give the person four more separate puffs, as in step two.

Step 4: If there is still no improvement, dial Triple Zero (000) for an ambulance. Keep giving the person four separate puffs every four minutes until emergency assistance arrives. If you don’t have a spacer, simply inhale four puffs directly by mouth.

Call Triple Zero (000) immediately if someone is not breathing, if their asthma suddenly becomes worse, or if someone is having a severe asthma attack.

If you’re not sure that it’s asthma, call Triple Zero (000) immediately.

Using asthma reliever medication in an emergency when breathing is difficult is unlikely to cause harm, even if the person doesn’t have asthma.
Impacts in your area:
  • A high risk of epidemic thunderstorm asthma is forecast for North East Victoria today.
  • We are in peak grass pollen season, so it is important that people with asthma remember to carry their asthma medication at all times.
This message was issued by the Department of Health .

The next update is expected by 11/11/2023 09:00 pm or as the situation changes.

For more information:
  • For more information on what thunderstorm asthma is, visit the Better Health Channel.
  • Monitor epidemic thunderstorm asthma forecasts.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#ThunderstormAsthma)
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: ADVICE - THUNDERSTORM ASTHMA - Prepare Now Incident Location: North East Victoria Issue Date: Saturday 11 November 2023, 11:53 am Next Update: Saturday 11 November 2023, 09:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/30950/moreinfo This Advice message is being issued for the North East weather district. - People may experience asthma symptoms or difficulty breathing due to thunderstorm activity. - Thunderstorm asthma can be triggered by a combination of high amounts of grass pollen in the air and a certain type of thunderstorm. For people who have asthma or hay fever this, can trigger severe asthma symptoms. - If you're experiencing wheezing, breathlessness, a feeling of tightness in the chest or a persistent cough, you may be having an asthma attack. - An asthma attack is serious and can be life threatening. If you develop symptoms follow your asthma management plan, or if you don’t have a plan follow the four steps of asthma first aid. Be aware of an increased chance of experiencing breathing difficulties or an asthma attack. Prepare now - carry your asthma reliever puffer with you at all times today. Call Triple Zero (000) immediately if someone is not breathing, if their asthma suddenly becomes worse or is not improving, or if the person is having an asthma attack and a reliever is not available.

properties.webHeadline: Today, Sat, 11 Nov 2023 has been declared a day of Total Fire Ban in the Mallee district(s) of Victoria.  No fires can be lit or be allowed to remain alight in the open air from 12:01 AM on Sat, 11 Nov 2023 until 11:59 PM Sat, 11 Nov 2023.
